Paper: Expert knowledge for automatic detection of bullies in social networks
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
Cyberbullying is defined as an aggressive, intentional
act carried out by a group or individual, using electronic forms of contact repeatedly
and over time against a victim who cannot easily defend him or herself
Data Collection process:
2 graduate studentns labeled the users as bullies or not 
with inter agreement Kappa of 0.78
Text Feature:
no profane words,
length of comment,
misspellings and short words,
comments targeted to someone
tf-idf
User info features:
hidden identities,
age of user,
period of membership,
no uploads,
no subscrptions,
no comments
Other features:
A) Experts: a panel of 12 experts in the area of cyberbullying was asked to answer questions about the features presented in Table 1. For each feature they indicated 1) the
likelihood that a bully user belongs to a certain category relevant for that feature and
2) the importance of that feature. The likelihood was indicated on four-point scale
‘Unlikely’, ‘Less likely’, ‘Likely’ and ‘Very likely’ corresponding to values 0.125,0.375, 0.625 and 0.875 respectively
B)MCES decision making systems
Comments:
2- We demonstrated that the expert system outperforms the machine
learning models and the hybrid approach results in a further but marginal improvement in prediction performance
1- compare three types of automatic detection: an expert system, supervised machine learning models, and a hybrid type combining the two.

Paper:
Hateful Symbols or Hateful People?
Predictive Features for Hate Speech Detection on Twitter
Definition of Cyber-Bullyning:
they define hate speech as negating the privileages of white people listed in (McIntosh (2003))
They provide a list of 12 charcteristics that describe hate speech  and compared against each tweet to label them
Dataset positive sample:
3,383 (21% - sexist sent by 612 users)
1,972 (12% - rascist sent by 9 users)
Data Collection process:
Crawled  from Twitter piblic API by using keywords like “MKR”, “asian drive”, “feminazi”,
“immigrant”, “nigger”, “sjw”, “WomenAgainstFeminism”,
“blameonenotall”, “islam terrorism”, “notallmen”,
“victimcard”, “victim card”, “arab terror”, “gamergate”,
“jsi
Text Feature: character n-gram
Other features:
1-most frquent words in racist anf sexist tweets.
2- avg and total length of tweets
Comments:
1- Feature engineering.
2-We find that using character n-grams of
lengths up to 4, along with gender as an additional
feature provides the best results.
3-location and length as features made the score worse.

Paper: Are You a Racist or Am I Seeing Things? Annotator Influence on Hate Speech Detection on Twitter
Data Collection process: labelled by experts and amatures on CrowdFlower platform
Text Feature:
POS, unigrams, characer ngram, token ngrm, 
word length, brown cluster
Comments:
We find that amateur annotators are more
likely than expert annotators to label items as
hate speech, and that systems trained on expert annotations outperform systems trained
on amateur annotations.
